docs.lead_paragraph: The Republicans’ road map to a “Stronger America” sticks to the tired themes of tax cuts and spending cuts, no matter the need or consequences.
docs.abstract: Editorial assesses budget resolution released by House Republicans and questions why Republicans continue to stick to tired themes of spending cuts and tax cuts, which will serve only to increase poverty and income inequality; notes that many of the spending cuts would disproportionately affect low- and modest-income Americans, and budget also would strip 16.4 million people of health insurance by repealing Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: The Republicans’ road map to a “Stronger America” sticks to the tired themes of tax cuts and spending cuts, no matter the need or consequences.

docs.lead_paragraph: To keep pace with insurers’ expectations, the renowned health system is trying to become as good at primary care as it is at performing complicated procedures.

headline.main: Cleveland Clinic Grapples With Changes in Health Care
headline.print_headline: The New Faces of Health Care

docs.abstract: Changes at the Cleveland Clinic, long respected as country's premier nonprofit health system, reflect overall struggle by health providers to adapt to shifting dynamics among insurers; clinic is trying to embrace primary care and chronic disease treatments, in addition to its traditional specialty practices, as it seeks to recover market share among insurers who are looking for systems that can manage all of a patient's needs.
docs.snippet: To keep pace with insurers’ expectations, the renowned health system is trying to become as good at primary care as it is at performing complicated procedures.

docs.lead_paragraph: Universal programs financed by broader taxes could appear unfair, but targeted social insurance financed by progressive taxes is likely to be stingy and politically weak.

headline.main: Patching Up the Social Safety Net
headline.print_headline: Patching Up Safety Net, Without Putting It at Risk

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column examines how Pres Obama's social initiatives, from food stamp expansion to the Affordable Care Act, have been specifically targeted toward needy; observes that strategy has fraught history, and that Wilbur Cohen, co-founder of Social Security in 1935, once observed that programs targeted at poor will eventually become poor themselves; examines risks such programs will face.
docs.snippet: Universal programs financed by broader taxes could appear unfair, but targeted social insurance financed by progressive taxes is likely to be stingy and politically weak.
